title: British security checks at ports used to smuggle the 39 migrants into UK 'was scaled back'
text:
British checks at ports used to smuggle the 39 migrants into the UK had been scaled back in the past 18 months, it was claimed last night.

Immigration sources said there were fewer officers being deployed to the Belgian port of Zeebrugge as manpower was diverted to deal with the migrant crisis at French ports.

They also raised concerns about the overstretched UK Border Force’s ability to target people smugglers.

British checks at ports used to smuggle the 39 migrants into the UK had been scaled back in the past 18 months, it was claimed last night. Pictured: The lorry in which 39 bodies were discovered in the trailer

Separately, the port’s chief harbourmaster admitted yesterday that just 1 per cent of sealed containers that leave Zeebrugge are X-rayed.

In a series of allegations about the state of Britain’s border security, residents living near Purfleet docks in Essex said the arrival of illegal migrants was an ‘open secret’.

There were also claims that border staff were issued with handcuffs after migrants began stabbing themselves so they would be taken to hospital.

The sealed refrigerated shipping container in which the 39 migrants were found dead arrived at Purfleet from Zeebrugge on Wednesday.

One source said: ‘There are only ad hoc searches at Purfleet but... every port of entry is causing us concern at the moment. It’s not good.’

Another source said British teams had worked closely with Belgian officials at Zeebrugge, but deployment of UK border agents was scaled back last year because of a lack of staff and funding. The source said: ‘We are not getting replacement staff when people move on, and I estimate we are short of several hundred staff nationwide. It is an exceptionally difficult time.’

Zeebrugge’s harbourmaster, Peter Degroote, last night admitted that the vast majority of sealed containers that arrive at the port do not have their contents examined. He said: ‘We do have a fixed X-ray scanner. The border checks for customs usually in Zeebrugge... is only for import into the EU. So for export there is very few checks.’

Immigration sources said there were fewer officers being deployed to the Belgian port of Zeebrugge as manpower was diverted to deal with the migrant crisis at French ports. Pictured: Police and forensic officers investigate the lorry

Pressed on how many sealed containers undergo these checks, Mr Degroote said: ‘I would say 1 per cent maybe.’

Between 4,000 and 7,000 containers pass through Zeebrugge each day, with roughly half bound for Britain. Port chief executive Joachim Coens stressed that one million euros is spent each year on security.

In the UK, one Border Force source said that colleagues had been issued with protective equipment after migrants who were found by search teams began self-harming.

The source said: ‘The few UKBF officers present were issued with sets of handcuffs and stab-proof vests because clandestine individuals were stabbing themselves to get taken to hospital.’

The sealed refrigerated shipping container in which the 39 migrants were found dead arrived at Purfleet from Zeebrugge on Wednesday

Residents in Purfleet said yesterday that the arrival of groups of migrants at the port was an ‘open secret’.

Janet Lilley, 61, said the area was a ‘magnet’ for migrants. She added: ‘Over the years we’ve found dozens of passports in the garden.’

Neighbour Susan Bridge, 47, claimed minibuses lined up to collect migrants, adding: ‘I wouldn’t say it was even a secret, to be honest.’

Thurrock Council said it was unable to comment on the claims. Essex Police were approached for comment.

The container in which the 39 people died had also travelled to Calais and Dunkirk in the week before its arrival in Essex, it has emerged.

GPS tracking data shows the refrigerated container made two trips across the Channel, The Times reported.

A Home Office spokesman said: ‘Border Force will always ensure it has the resources it needs to keep our borders secure and is currently recruiting up to 1,000 new staff.’

authors: Andrew Levy For The Daily Mail
